javadoc:
General resource management class that provides a convenient way of accessing external resources used in Ghidra.

There is a known problem with Java's {@link MediaTracker} that can cause deadlocks. The various methods of this class that create {@link ImageIcon}s will do so by loading image bytes directly, as opposed to using the flawed constructor {@link ImageIcon#ImageIcon(Image)}.

methods.javadoc:
Finds a resource with a given name. This method returns null if no
 resource with this name is found. The rules for searching resources
 associated with a given class are implemented by the defining class
 loader of the class.
@param filename "partially" qualified resource filename to get, e.g.,
        "images/go-home.png" would look for the file named 'home.gif' in
        the 'images' subdirectory of the 'resources' package,
        following the search rules defined by your CLASSPATH and
        return an InputStream if found; null if it cannot load the resource.
@return the URL
methods.name: getResource
methods.comment:
Finds a resource with a given name. This method returns null if no
 resource with this name is found. The rules for searching resources
 associated with a given class are implemented by the defining class
 loader of the class.

params.name: filename
params.comment:
"partially" qualified resource filename to get, e.g.,
        "images/go-home.png" would look for the file named 'home.gif' in
        the 'images' subdirectory of the 'resources' package,
        following the search rules defined by your CLASSPATH and
        return an InputStream if found; null if it cannot load the resource.

methods.javadoc:
Finds a resource with a given name. This method returns null if no resource
 with this name is found. The rules for searching resources associated with a
 given class are implemented by the defining class loader of the class.
@param filename "partially" qualified resource filename to get, e.g., "images/home.gif" 
        would look for the file named 'home.gif' in the 'images' subdirectory of 
        the 'resources' package, following the search rules defined by your 
        CLASSPATH and return an InputStream if found; null if it cannot load the resource.
@return the input stream
methods.name: getResourceAsStream
methods.comment:
Finds a resource with a given name. This method returns null if no resource
 with this name is found. The rules for searching resources associated with a
 given class are implemented by the defining class loader of the class.

params.name: filename
params.comment:
"partially" qualified resource filename to get, e.g., "images/home.gif" 
        would look for the file named 'home.gif' in the 'images' subdirectory of 
        the 'resources' package, following the search rules defined by your 
        CLASSPATH and return an InputStream if found; null if it cannot load the resource.

methods.name: getResourceFile
methods.comment: Locates a File resource by the given name

params.name: filename
params.comment: the filename

return.comment: the File for the given resource; null if there is no such file

methods.name: getResource
methods.comment: Searches the given set of directory paths for the given filename

params.name: searchPaths
params.comment: the paths

params.name: filename
params.comment: the filename

return.comment: the URL of the first matching file

methods.name: getResources
methods.comment:
Search the classpath for files in the classpath entry/dirName 
 location that have the given extension.  In null is passed for the 
 extension, then all files found in the given dir names will be returned.  In this 
 way, null is a wildcard.

 This method differs from #getResource(String) in that this method finds 
 multiple matches.

params.name: dirName
params.comment: the name of the sub-directory under which to search

params.name: extension
params.comment: the extension that matching files must possess

return.comment: set of URLs in the given directory that end with the given extension

methods.name: getResourceNames
methods.comment:
Search the classpath for files in the classpath entry/dirName 
 location that have the given extension.  In null is passed for the 
 extension, then all files found in the given dir names will be returned.  In this 
 way, null is a wildcard.

 The names returned from this method are relative and are meant to be used in a 
 later callback to this class for methods such as #loadImage(String) or
 #getResource(String).

params.name: dirName
params.comment: the name of the directory under which to search

params.name: extension
params.comment: the extension that matching files must possess

return.comment: set of filenames in the given directory that end with the given extension

methods.name: findResources
methods.comment:
Search the directory for files ending in the given extension and add them to the list 
 that is returned

params.name: set
params.comment: the set to which resource names will be added

params.name: file
params.comment: directory, e.g., "resources/defaultTools"

params.name: dirName
params.comment: name of sub-directory, e.g. "defaultTools"

params.name: extension
params.comment: file extension to look for

methods.name: searchJarFile
methods.comment:
Search the given jar filename for files in 
 resources with the given file extension.

params.name: set
params.comment: the set to which resource names will be added

params.name: file
params.comment: jar or zip filename

params.name: resourceDirName
params.comment: name of resource directory, e.g. "defaultTools"

params.name: extension
params.comment: file extension to look for

methods.name: getScaledIcon
methods.comment: Creates a scaled ImageIcon from the given icon.

params.name: icon
params.comment: the icon to scale

params.name: width
params.comment: the width of the new icon

params.name: height
params.comment: the height of the new icon

params.name: hints
params.comment: scaling hints (see BufferedImage#getScaledInstance(int, int, int)

methods.name: getScaledIcon
methods.comment:
Creates a scaled ImageIcon from the given icon with scaling of 
 Image#SCALE_AREA_AVERAGING

params.name: icon
params.comment: the icon to scale

params.name: width
params.comment: the width of the new icon

params.name: height
params.comment: the height of the new icon

methods.name: getDisabledIcon
methods.comment: Get the disabled rendering of the given icon.

params.name: icon
params.comment: The icon to disable.

methods.name: getDisabledIcon
methods.comment: Get the disabled rendering of the given imageIcon.

params.name: icon
params.comment: The icon to disable.

methods.name: getDisabledIcon
methods.comment:
Returns a disabled icon while allowing the caller to control the brightness of the icon
 returned

params.name: icon
params.comment: The icon to disable.

params.name: brightnessPercent
params.comment: The level of brightness (0-100, where 100 is the brightest).

return.comment: a disabled version of the original icon.

methods.name: getImageIconFromImage
methods.comment:
Creates an image icon from the given image.  This method will create an ImageIcon
 the "safe" way by avoiding the constructor 
 ImageIcon#ImageIcon(Image), which can
 trigger problems with Java's MediaTracker.

params.name: imageName
params.comment: A textual description of the image; may be null

params.name: image
params.comment: The image to use for creating an ImageIcon.

methods.name: getImageIcon
methods.comment:
Returns an ImageIcon for the given icon.  If the value is already an ImageIcon, then
 that object is returned; otherwise, an ImageIcon will be created the safe
 way.

params.name: icon
params.comment: The icon to convert

methods.name: getIconName
methods.comment:
Get the name of this icon.  The value is usually going to be the URL from which the icon 
 was loaded

params.name: icon
params.comment: the icon for which the name is desired

methods.name: loadImage
methods.comment:
Load the image using the specified bytes. The image icon will
 be cached using the image name. The bytes must have been
 read from an image file containing a supported image format,
 such as GIF, JPEG, or (as of 1.3) PNG.

params.name: imageName
params.comment: the name of the image

params.name: imageBytes
params.comment: the bytes of the image

return.comment: the image icon stored in the bytes

methods.name: loadImage
methods.comment:
Load and scale the image specified by filename; returns null if problems occur trying to load
 the file.

params.name: filename
params.comment: name of file to load, e.g., "images/home.gif"

params.name: width
params.comment: - the width to scale the image to

params.name: height
params.comment: - the height to scale the image to

methods.name: loadImage
methods.comment:
Load the image specified by filename; returns the default bomb icon
 if problems occur trying to load the file.

params.name: filename
params.comment: name of file to load, e.g., "images/home.gif"

return.comment: the image icon stored in the bytes

methods.name: loadImages
methods.comment:
Load the images specified by filenames; substitutes the default bomb icon
 if problems occur trying to load an individual file.

params.name: filenames
params.comment: vararg list of string filenames (ie. "images/home.gif")

return.comment:
list of ImageIcons with each image, problem / missing images replaced with
 the default icon.

methods.name: reloadImage
methods.comment:
A convenience method to force the image denoted by filename to be read 
 from disk and to not use the cached version

params.name: filename
params.comment: name of file to load, e.g., "images/home.gif"

return.comment: the image icon stored in the bytes

methods.javadoc:
Returns paths to search in test mode when finding resources.

This allows us to have our Eclipse development environment match the gradle test environment with respect to how resources are found. Specifically, in Eclipse, resources are found on the classpath. Further, in Eclipse, the 'test' and 'test.slow' folders are on the classpath. Even more, Eclipse will include these test folders as transitive dependencies for submodules. Contrastingly, gradle will not include transitive test dependencies. So, we add this code here so that we do not have to update each gradle build file that needs resources defined in a parent modules test resources. @return the paths
methods.name: getTestSearchPaths
methods.comment:
Returns paths to search in test mode when finding resources. 
 
 This allows us to have our Eclipse development environment match the gradle test
 environment with respect to how resources are found.  Specifically, in Eclipse, resources
 are found on the classpath.  Further, in Eclipse, the 'test' and 'test.slow' folders are
 on the classpath.  Even more, Eclipse will include these test folders as transitive 
 dependencies for submodules.  Contrastingly, gradle will not include transitive test
 dependencies.  So, we add this code here so that we do not have to update each gradle
 build file that needs resources defined in a parent modules test resources.

name: ResourceManager
comment:
General resource management class that provides a convenient
 way of accessing external resources used in Ghidra.
 
 
 There is a known problem with Java's MediaTracker that can cause deadlocks.  The various
 methods of this class that create ImageIcons will do so by loading image bytes directly,
 as opposed to using the flawed constructor ImageIcon#ImageIcon(Image).
